values: Well, I figure it's been awhile since I've done a true life/fandom update here. We'll start with Lydia, of course. She'll be eight months old in about a week and is definitely keeping us on our toes. She eats everything (whether it's actually edible or not), talks and babbles all the time, and is fascinated by any new thing. She has two teeth, sits up on her own perfectly, finally decided that she likes rolling around (especially in her crib or when I'm trying to change her diaper), and while she's not crawling yet, she's definitely getting close. Unfortunately, she'll soon be sporting a helmet twenty-three hours a day. :( She's been in physical therapy for a few months because of torticollis (basically, she usually has her head cocked to one side) and it's caused the left side of her head to get flattened. So the helmet will get her head evened out, and supposedly may help her even hold her head level, too. I know, I know, in the grand scheme of things this is pretty minor and if this is the worst problem she'll ever face, then she's got it made. I just can't imagine wearing that helmet will be comfortable, especially when she sleeps. Gix is still doing fine too. Still working at the university, still composing and arranging, will be the music director for the community theater he's involved with for the third year in a row this coming June. He just recently had another one of his flute choir pieces have its premiere with a featured low flutes expert soloist: https://unomusic.wordpress.com/2016/03/04/eminent-low-flutes-specialist-peter-sheridan-visits-uno/ As for me, I'm still working for the city and playing in flute choir (not the one Gix wrote that piece for, lol... I'm in a much smaller, less formal one). Seeing as I've barely lost any pregnancy weight (and was overweight to begin with even before I got pregnant) I'm trying to get into the habit of working out a couple times a week. Of course, since I work full time, spend the evening with Lydia until her bedtime (around 7 or 7:30 usually), and also since Lydia is a very early riser (between 5 and 6 most mornings... urgh, can't taaaaaake iiiiiiiiiiiittt...) I don't have a whole lot of time in the evenings, especially considering I've been going to bed pretty early lately because I know that little chatterbox baby in the next room will be waking me up at 5:30 lol. Plus there's all the house chores and upkeep that we can't really put off anymore, so I've been trying to keep on top of all of that too. So as you can imagine, I really haven't had much time for much else. I've been scrapbooking and coloring a little bit, but mostly I've been playing Pokemon on my 3DS. So here's the thing--despite being a 90's kid, I've never actually played any Pokemon games until now. Obviously I knew what it was (I distinctly recall my classmates in sixth grade trading Pokemon cards during lunch), but seeing as the only video games I ever played as a kid were actually computer games, it was just something I never got in to. Gix, on the other hand, is a huge gamer and was really determined to get me hooked on it. I actually started playing X back when I was pregnant with Lydia, believe it or not. I played about halfway through the game but then kind of forgot about it until after Lydia was born. I then finished the game, caught all of the Pokemon I could in that game, and then Gix so so kindly decided to fuel my oncoming addiction and bought me Omega Ruby out of the blue lol. So as of right now, with his help, I have a living dex of 713 Pokemon species, and the only ones I'm missing are the mythical ones that will be released throughout the year anyway. (I was super excited to get my Mew and Celebi!) I've even been going on the GTS to get various form differences of them too. I am a little too proud of the fact that I have acquired all of the non-event patterns of Vivillon. It took a lot of doing! lol so anyway, this whole paragraph is to shake a fist at my husband for getting me hooked on this game... it was no surprise that I, being the completionist I am, literally had to "catch em all". I still haven't lost my love for cartoons, but it's been pretty dormant right now. The cartoon I've been watching the most of is Mickey Mouse Clubhouse, which really isn't too bad a show for the little kid set. Lydia LOVES it, especially the Hot Dog Dance--she freaks out when it comes on at the end of every show.:p But fear not, friends, for these next few years are shaping up to be a great time for us fans of nostalgic cartoons... potentially. I'll wrap this entry up as if it were old times and give my thoughts on two old favorites of mine that are getting rebooted soon. First, The Powerpuff Girls reboot. My feelings on this are... mixed. I think it's horrible that Cartoon Network didn't even ask the original VAs of the Girls to reprise their roles (especially learning that they all said that they would have happily done so if they had been asked back). I suppose it's nice that they're giving new female VAs their time in the spotlight. But it still seems really suspect that the rest of the (mostly male) cast still have the same voices, you know what I mean? And watching the clips that CN have been posting to the PPG Facebook page lately, I'm less than impressed with the new choices. Blossom sounds super generic, and Bubbles... she just doesn't sound like Bubbles at all. She's missing that sweet, bubbly quality to the voice that's obviously necessary for the role. I can live with the new Buttercup... she's passable and is obviously making an effort to infuse the voice with Buttercup's spunk and personality. But Blossom and Bubbles' new voices just aren't doing anything for me. With that said, I am pretty pleased with the action I felt from the new clips. It may not sound like the Powerpuff Girls, but it looks like the Powerpuff Girls, if you know what I mean? I'm glad that the Girls' updated look didn't stray too far from the originals either. Watching the clips, I thought, "Yeah, I recognize this. I recognize this as PPG." If I turn the volume off, I can enjoy it even more! ;) I will probably tentatively be giving the show a chance when it debuts... whenever it debuts. Next month, I think? The one reboot I am super excited for is the DuckTales reboot coming next year: http://blogs.disney.com/oh-my-disney/2016/03/07/new-ducktales-first-image/ LOOK AT THAT TEASER IMAGE. MY DREAMS HAVE COME TRUE. Okay, so calming down a bit, the majority of the criticism I've seen regarding this first look is that the style looks too similar to the new Mickey Mouse shorts, so let me just go on the record and say that I LOVE THE SHIT out of those shorts (the humor, the design, the plots... everything), so of course I'm totally on board with this redesign. My biggest fear when they first announced this was that it would be CGI, so I am of course relieved and ecstatic to see them doing more with this traditional style! And of course, if Donald will be more of a major character this time around, that would be the cherry on top. Hoping that underused characters from the original show like Gladstone Gander and Ludwig Von Drake (still my fave Disney character) get some more love, too! I'll wrap this rambling entry up now. Hope everyone's doing well. :)

So on Facebook, I have the Fairly Oddparents page listed under my "liked" TV shows. I liked the page ages ago, in fact. I am very fond of the show... the first three seasons. I've been saying that since even before Poof was born, and I've only felt the need to stress "the first three seasons ONLY!" only more and more since then.

This means that I saw the stuff they posted awhile ago about... omg... ADDING A NEW CHARACTER! Yes, a show that already has about ten million characters, they got the bright idea to not only add a new one, but a new MAIN character... a stupid looking fairy dog, and from what I've heard he's absolutely horrible. Clearly the writers were running out of ideas. Poof was their first attempt at a saving throw. It was a desperate measure, really. And honestly, that one didn't work out too badly. I've seen some Poof episodes and most of what I've seen were pretty solid. They just needed to firmly establish that this is the new status quo, stop adding even more characters to the cast--oh goddammit you guys.

So first the dog, and then not too long ago, I see them start teasing this new character. "We're adding a new character to the show!" Yeah, try doing something you haven't done a million times already. Okay, so it's a new girl at school... whatever. Timmy's new neighbor... okay, whatever, seems stupid but harmless...

"Timmy has to SHARE his fairies!"

Oh you have got to be kidding me.

Anyway, I hate myself, so I just watched the episode today on my lunch break.

I don't know what to say. I really don't. What can you say about a show that clearly ran out of ideas at least three seasons ago but is still desperately trying to churn out new material? What else can you say about an episode that so thoroughly changes the whole dynamic of the show (not even Poof or that damn dog did so to this degree) that you have to change the friggin' THEME SONG because of it?!

And, more importantly... why do I care? I'm nearly thirty years old, I'm a grown-ass adult with a spouse and kid and full-time job and I'm obviously not in the demographic of this show at all. In fact, seeing as I first started watching it in high school, I never WAS really in the demographic even to begin with. So why DO I care?

I guess I care because of what the show USED to be. It was funny, it was clever, it had characters that you cared about. Was it a perfect show? Not by any means. It always had its issues, even in the beginning. But back then, the strengths usually outweighed the weaknesses and produced a show that was worth watching. Now, it's just a show that's... there. And it's been giving out dying gasps for ages now and yet no one has the mercy to just put it out of its misery.

The show deserved better than this, you guys. It deserved to end on a high note, or at least end with some of its dignity still intact. I don't think they can end it like that anymore, not after what they've done to it. It's just too far gone now.

I know, I know... I shouldn't care. I shouldn't care about some silly little kids' show. But this show meant a lot to me. It was actually the fandom that led me to DeviantArt (not that I'm on DA anymore...). I churned out so much fanfic for it. Cosmo/Wanda was my first real OTP and I still adore their relationship. It's why I was okay with the introduction of Poof--and I'm still alright with him as a character. True, the "add a baby to the main cast" is usually a last-ditch effort to keep the show going and it usually backfires, but come on, this is Cosmo and Wanda's baby, something that most of us FOP fans (especially us Cosmo/Wanda shippers) had been wanting to see since the beginning, so I can't hate the character at all. But... let's be honest. The show should have ended there. It really should have ended before there, actually.

Right now, I'm honestly embarrassed to admit to liking the show. Even with that all-important qualifier "only the first three seasons!". It's just been stomped so thoroughly into the ground that it's even tainted my memories of what it used to be.

I do have a couple of early episodes on a flash drive somewhere, though... oh yes, and there's also this channel!

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCA8OH52te7LLg_O9T7lZFEA/featured

Looks to be the first four seasons... and it's apparently the production company behind those seasons, so it's doubtful the channel will be taken down (fingers crossed!).

I think I know what I'm watching tonight to get the bad taste of the newest season out of my head.

I'm posting this a little earlier than usual, but since one of the questions is "what WILL you be doing for Christmas" as opposed to "what DID you do for Christmas" I figure I've been posting it too late in previous years anyway. No, I don't know why I keep doing these. I guess I like looking back on them down the road and seeing where I was at the end of each year. 1. What did you do in 2015 that you'd never done before? Gave birth. lol that was a trip. 2. Did you keep your new years' resolutions, and will you make more for next year? I didn't make any... but I actually am making one for next year, and that's to severely limit my Facebook time, if not entirely quit it cold turkey. Why? It's a presidential election year... enough said. (I also don't like any of the candidates... no, not even Bernie Sanders... but admitting that on my Facebook page would probably make about half of my friends faint in shock lol. The cult of Bernie is strong with my friends.) 3. Did anyone close to you give birth? I did, do I count? lol. Actually, a lot of people I know had babies this year. Seemed my Facebook feed was overflowing with babies (when it wasn't overflowing with politics). 4. Did anyone close to you die? A former co-worker of mine from the library. It was a really sad situation. She and three of her friends from college were driving at night and swerved to hit a deer, and hit an oncoming car instead. All four of them died instantly. They were all really young, too--early 20's. Such a horrible loss. :( 5. What countries did you visit? None... lol this question. I haven't visited a different country since 2008 (not that I don't want to, but it's kind of not feasible at this point in my life) 6. What would you like to have in 2016 that you lacked in 2015? Uh... a flat stomach? lol 7. What date from 2015 will remain etched upon your memory, and why? July 17th. Happy birthday sweet baby girl! 8. What was your biggest achievement of the year? Lydia, and the house! Both pretty freaking important. :D 9. What was your biggest failure? Hmm. The only thing that comes to mind was failing to breastfeed, but honestly, I prefer formula feeding much better anyway, and at least I recognized that breastfeeding wasn't working before going back to work and trying to pump, so I don't see it as a failure as much as a blessing in disguise. :) 10. Did you suffer illness or injury? Ugh. You know, I hardly ever get sick, but I don't know if it's from giving birth or what... but I've basically had a cold since September. With a couple of really awful days of that cold, too. I thought I was finally getting over it in November, but then it either came back with a vengeance or I caught a different one. Again, I think I'm finally getting over this one... please please PLEASE don't let me suddenly get it back again! 11. What was the best thing you bought? DA HOUSSSSSSSSSE 12. Whose behavior merited celebration? Everyone who's helped me with Lydia! The nurses at the hospital, my OBGYN, Lydia's pediatrician, the lactation consultant (even though I ultimately threw in the towel, I wouldn't have lasted even that long without her)--and especially my mom, mother-in-law, and the friend of me and Gix who we kind of consider our in-town mom, who were all willing to watch Lydia while we were in daycare limbo for a few weeks! (Long story.) 13. Whose behavior made you appalled and depressed? A lot of public figures, which is why I've cut myself off from the news (and by extension the internet) as much as humanly possible. Last year's answer, and also see above re. my new year's resolution. 14. Where did most of your money go? Also, stuff for Lydia, obviously. 15. What did you get really, really, really excited about? Lydia! And the house! 16. What song will always remind you of 2015? Not a song from 2015 obviously, but I discovered it this year and found it such a happy, relaxing, beautiful song. 17. Compared to this time last year, are you: i. happier or sadder? Happier. :) ii. thinner or fatter? Errr... about the same, I guess, but that's obviously not to say that my weight didn't go up and down this past year. I may be a little fatter than this time last year. I don't think I've lost the last few pregnancy pounds, and I haven't worked up the guts to step on the scale to check lol iii. richer or poorer? Errrrrrrrr... again, probably about the same, but not because things there stayed stagnant either. 18. What do you wish you'd done more of? I don't know. I don't really have the time to be wishing to do more of anything, really. 19. What do you wish you'd done less of? See above? I mean, I'm getting what needs to be done done lol 20. How will you be spending Christmas? My in-laws are coming up on December 22nd in their RV, with my stepson. They'll stay until Christmas Day, so we'll have Christmas with them at our house Christmas Eve. Christmas Day Gix, the kids (damn that's weird to type), and I will go to my parents' house for that gathering and possibly stay the night--we haven't decided yet. 21. At any point in the past year did you do something that you consider completely out of your usual character? Have a baby lololol everyone likes to remind me how I used to declare I'd NEVER have kids 22. Did you fall in love in 2015? Nah. I guess platonically/maternally with Lydia, but I don't really think that counts for this question. 23. How many one-night stands? Zero 24. What was your favorite TV program? Didn't watch a whole lot of TV. The only new show I've been watching consistently is the Muppets, and I've also been staying on top of Big Bang Theory, and for fun/relaxing we usually pull up some Let's Make a Deal. (Did I mention Gix got a Roku? Now we actually can watch TV, lol) 25. Do you hate anyone now that you didn't hate this time last year? Not really. 26. What was the best book you read this year? argh I feel bad. I hardly read anything this year other than pregnancy/baby books. 27. What was your greatest musical discovery? I dunno. 28. What did you want and get? A baby! And a house! Two for two! 29. What did you want and not get? I honestly can't think of anything. :) 30. What was your favorite film of this year? Hmm. I saw Jurassic World, Inside Out, and Peanuts (I don't think I've seen any other new films this year) and they were all good... but I can probably fully say that my favorite film of this year I haven't seen yet. STAR WARS THE FORCE AWAKENS BABY! I am SO FRIGGIN' EXCITED! No spoilers or I will end you. :P (next day edit) The stars aligned and I was actually able to see Star Wars today, and yes, best movie of the year. But damn, way to pull out my heart and stab it repeatedly! It will take awhile to emotionally heal from that... 31. What did you do on your birthday, and how old were you? We left Lydia at my parents', went to the Husker game against Northwestern and stayed for half of it (they sucked, as was their normal operating mode this year), and then went back to Omaha and started moving more things from the apartment to the house, as we had just closed on it four days previously. Then we went out to eat at a Mexican restaurant for supper. I turned 29! Can't believe I'm nearly 30, gah. Where has my life gone?! 32. What one thing would have made your year immeasurably more satisfying? Uh... you know, 2015 has been a great year overall, so I'm having trouble thinking of anything. Losing all of the pregnancy weight (and the extra weight I was carrying before I even got pregnant)? Yeah, that would have been nice. Let's see if I can't manage that next year! 33. How would you describe your personal fashion concept in 2015? Maternity clothes. Sadly I'm still wearing a lot of them lol. I have a bunch of jeans that do fit me, though--hooray for elastic waist jeans! :) 34. What kept you sane? Phht. Myself, I guess? This year, especially the second half of it, has been crazy, but I haven't felt like I was teetering on the edge of sanity (except for those couple of days after Lydia was born that I got a touch of the baby blues, but that's pretty common from what I understand). 35. Which celebrity/public figure did you fancy the most? None 36. What political issue stirred you the most? Probably the Syrian refugees, and I'll be the first to admit my new-mom hormones probably had a lot to do with that. I still can't think about the picture of the little boy's body washed up on the shore without tearing up a bit. :( Needless to say, I'm fully supportive of refugees and think the USA should take some in. 37. Who did you miss? Can't really think of anyone. 38. Who was the best new person you met? Lydia! She's such a sweetheart. :) Again I admit that I'm biased. 39. Tell us a valuable life lesson you learned in 2015. I don't know. I feel like if I learn a lesson from anything, it takes a long time for me to realize that a lesson was learned. 40. Quote a song lyric that sums up your year: I never answer this question, I should just remove it lol

I wasn't planning on writing this, because trust me, I don't think strangers (or even people I know) care too much about my birth story, but I wanted to write it all down while it was still fresh in my mind, and I also am thinking about submitting it to a mom group I'm in on Facebook (because despite my thoughts, I actually do enjoy reading other people's birth stories to an extent). It's also kind of long, but I feel like I need to start at the beginning (that is, the beginning of James's and my relationship) to tell the whole story.

I don't go into too much graphic detail, but general warnings for talking about miscarriage, pregnancy, and childbirth in here. Also, again, it's long. Don't say I didn't warn you. :P (Actually, again, I don't care if anyone reads this or not... just wanted to write it down for myself)

<lj-cut text="Birth story.">In high school and college, I always said I'd never get married or have kids. It figures, then, that I ended up marrying a divorced dad. When James and I first started dating, I told him I didn't want kids, and he told me he didn't want any more kids, so we seemed to be in agreement there. However, after a few months, James admitted to me that he'd had a change of heart and actually did want to have children with me. I was upset, to say the least, but after spending enough time with Asher, his son, and realizing that taking care of a kid wasn't so bad (and also seeing how good of a dad James was), by the time we were married I was not opposed to having children of my own. I still didn't exactly *want* children, but I didn't *not* want them either. James and I were married in August 2012 and I went off birth control around that time. We decided to not actively try for a baby, but to not actively prevent a pregnancy from happening, either.

Fast forward to December 30, 2013. We have Asher during the summer and every other Christmas and this Christmas he was with us. I had taken off some time from work to watch him, and that particular day I was finding him difficult to deal with. In an attempt to have a little peace, I went to the bathroom, and figured I should take a pregnancy test while I was at it. I hadn't had a period since early November, but my periods are usually irregular, and I had taken a pregnancy test right before we picked up Asher for the holidays which had turned out negative. But this one, lo and behold, was positive. I was not happy, to put it lightly. I even remember crying a bit, and not from happiness. How, I thought, could I take care of my own baby 24/7 when I could barely handle two weeks with my stepson, who I logically knew is a very easy and well-behaved kid? I even thought for a moment that I hoped I would have a miscarriage, a thought that haunts me to this day. I told James the news when he got home from work. He could tell I was a bit upset and had to comfort me, but he could barely contain his excitement. So much so, in fact, that he immediately called his parents to tell them. I remember telling him "isn't it a little early for that yet?" Going off of my last period, I was seven weeks pregnant at that time.

Since he had told his parents, I reluctantly figured I'd better tell mine. Of course none of our parents could keep it a secret from our families, and since I especially have a large family, a lot of people were in on our "little secret". I scheduled what I believed would be my twelve week appointment on January 22 and asked everyone to keep it off of Facebook until that time.

At that appointment, we were surprised to find out that the baby was only measuring about eight weeks. But then I remembered how the pregnancy test I had taken right before Christmas came up negative, which it shouldn't have been if I had been as far along as I thought I was. I told the sonographer that I had irregular periods which would account for the baby not measuring how it was "supposed" to. Other than that, the baby had a strong heartbeat and looked perfectly healthy. I was only eight weeks along, not twelve, but since I had told my family I'd be making the pregnancy public that day, along with a successful ultrasound, I went ahead and announced my pregnancy on Facebook. It was a bit of a bittersweet day for me as my grandmother died of leukemia that day, so I was glad that my dad had told her about my pregnancy beforehand. My new due date was September 4, 2014.

On the night of Saturday, February 8, I noticed some light spotting as I was getting ready for bed. I quickly looked it up and found that usually it was nothing too concerning. I wasn't in any pain, so I figured I'd just keep an eye on it and hope that it stopped eventually. I spotted all day Sunday, and Sunday night I told James that if I was still spotting in the morning, I wanted to have it checked out. Monday morning I wasn't just spotting. I was bleeding like a full-on period. I still wasn't having any cramps or pain, but I new I needed to go to the hospital. We both called in to work and went to the ER. After meeting with a doctor briefly I was wheeled into the ultrasound room (which I found strange because I was perfectly capable of walking). The sonographer told me she wanted to do a vaginal ultrasound, so I had to go to the bathroom and wipe up as best I can. When I did I was actually passing blood clots. I got back on the table and she poked around, and showed me the screen saying "there's your baby!" Then she turned the screen away from me and continued to look around. James was watching the screen too. I knew before they even told me. They didn't have any huge expression changes or start bawling or anything like that, but it was just so quiet in that room for a few moments and I just knew. Finally the sonographer said to me, very apologetically, "I'm sorry, but I can't find the heartbeat." James later told me that the embryo was only measuring about eight and a half weeks, not the ten and a half weeks it should have been. It had died just a few days after our first ultrasound.

I won't go into the nitty-gritty of the miscarriage, but needless to say it was very painful, both physically and emotionally. Logically I knew that I had done nothing to cause it, and yet I kept thinking back to my "I hope I miscarry" thought when I had first found out I was pregnant. James, if anything, took it even harder than I had, and spent the next week or so just holed up in Asher's room, barely leaving and barely talking when he did venture out. I told him that even though there was no real way of knowing, I felt that the baby had been a girl, and even though we had picked out both a boy name and a girl name, we began to refer to the miscarried child by a different name than the one we had picked: Anna. In some ways it helped to name her, in other ways it made it worse.

I don't really believe in fate or destiny, but I wanted there to be some reason why I had to have that miscarriage. The only reason I could think of was so that I could get pregnant in the time between the miscarriage and Septmeber 4th, the due date. Anna had to die so that our hypothetical other child could live. Again, we weren't trying to get pregnant, but I cannot tell you how inwardly devastating it was when I kept on getting my period. September 4 finally came... and I had my period a few days later. So much for everything having a reason. October my period came as well.

Then came Veteran's Day. James and I had just gotten home from band practice and I was planning on relaxing with a glass of wine before bed. My period was technically a few days late, although like I said, having irregular periods meant that this wasn't a big deal at all for me. I actually remember telling James "I'm going to take this pregnancy test just to make sure I'm not pregnant, and then open up that bottle of wine." I took it, and... two lines. One was very faint. "So what does it say?" James asked (he'd still been hoping I'd get pregnant again after all this time). "Uh... I don't know?" I answered back. It was honestly so faint I thought I was seeing things.  I took another one and same thing. "I guess I'd better not have that wine," I told James. Pulled up a due date estimator online--due July 15th, 2015. James and I were smiling, but they were such cautious and nervous smiles. I didn't have to tell him this time to not tell the family right away. I was four weeks, six days along.

My OB's office had me come in for an ultrasound the next month. It was pretty much the same as the last time--the baby was measuring eight weeks (although at least this time the timeline was as we expected) with a strong, steady heartbeat. But since we'd seen all that with Anna, I still wasn't getting my hopes up. We visited my in-laws for Christmas a few weeks later and we knew we'd have to let them know, so we got them coffee mugs that said "Grandma/Grandpa Round 2, Coming July 2015". They were ecstatic! We called Asher that day and let him know too--he was only mildly interested as his mother had just had a baby and having a baby sibling was nothing new to him. A few days later we were at my parents' and told them as well. My parents had actually wanted to take us all on a family vacation in July, and I had to keep deflecting my dad's questions about what days in July would work for me until everyone was in the room and I finally let the cat out the bag. Luckily my parents didn't mind their summer plans getting a massive overhaul. I was about eleven weeks along at this time, and still no spotting (I was honestly expecting it every day), so I finally decided to make a Christmas announcement on Facebook as well. But I knew I wouldn't breathe easily until the next ultrasound on January 2nd. This was the optional ultrasound to check for different conditions such as Down syndrome. When I told my mom that, she asked me what I would do if i found my baby had Down syndrome or something else--I think she was worried that I would abort it. I just shrugged and told her we'd prepare for it, but honestly the medical conditions being tested for weren't why I had scheduled that ultrasound. I just wanted to make sure that the baby was still alive in there.

That was honestly the best ultrasound ever. The eight week ultrasound basically looked like a little stationary jellybean. At the twelve week one, not only was the baby moving around like crazy, but it was very easy to make out all the body parts--the face, the hands and feet, everything! For the first time I wasn't feeling trepidation about this pregnancy--well, as much trepidation, anyway. The baby wasn't ever in the right position to check for the Down syndrome markers, so I was offered the chance to come in again in a few days. I took it--again, not because I had any concern over Down syndrome, but just because I wanted another ultrasound to make sure everything was still alright. Everything checked out fine, which meant our next ultrasound was at twenty weeks, or the start of March.

It was around this month--January, month four of my pregnancy--that I started getting so-called "morning" sickness. I never had any symptoms in the first trimester (in either pregnancy) but suddenly I was puking and nauseous at the start of the second trimester, against what all pregnancy guidebooks claimed. James was a saint running to Walgreens in the middle of the night to get me things to settle my stomach. Even with finally getting pregnancy symptoms, I still worried, feeling every day that I was going to lose this pregnancy too. Going in for my sixteen-week checkup and hearing the heartbeat was reassuring, for that day at least. So was my blooming baby bump. But as I couldn't feel any kicks yet, I spent pretty much every day afraid that something was going to happen. The twenty-week ultrasound couldn't come fast enough. James was anxious to know the sex, but again, I just wanted to see that the baby was alive and healthy. James really wanted a girl, and before we went in I had to make sure he was mentally prepared for the possibility of another boy and wouldn't be completely devastated by the news--while mentally preparing myself for not being able to find a heartbeat, which I still felt was going to happen.

Thankfully, I was wrong. The baby was growing as expected, but once again very uncooperative and not in the right position to check for sex or some of the other measurements the sonographer had to take. So we had to go in yet again for another ultrasound in a few days. The baby was a bit more obliging that day, and when the sonographer told us "looks like you're having a girl!" James couldn't have been more thrilled. I ran by the girl name we had decided on way back in our first pregnancy to make sure we both still liked it--Lydia Jane. We did. Now I was halfway through the pregnancy, my baby girl was healthy and growing, and she had a name. (Which we kept secret.) It was around that time that I finally started to be able to feel her move. It was sporadic at first, but eventually it became fairly regular. This helped ease my mind a bit from constantly worrying if she was okay, but at the same time I would still get a bit panicky if I hadn't felt her move in awhile. She wasn't a super-active baby who kept me up all night, but every time I did start worrying, she'd eventually give me a little jab to let me know all was well.

When I was around 33 weeks I was diagnosed with gestational diabetes. It was a bit of a drag to have to make changes to my diet and check my blood four times a day, and since I was diagnosed rather late in my pregnancy I was terrified of having a huge baby, especially since I myself was a rather large baby (and my birth legitimately gave my mother PTSD).  But there were perks to having GD, like being told to snack more often (beautiful words for a pregnant woman to hear!) and also more ultrasounds! Luckily she was not only at the average weight and size for her gestational age, but she had also settled down into a head-first position after being transverse fora while. The only thing of slight concern during that ultrasound was that the amniotic fluid was on the low side of okay levels. My OB said they'd be keeping an eye on that, because if the levels got too much lower that probably meant that the placenta wasn't working as it should and I'd need to be induced. By that time, especially once I hit 37 weeks and was full-term, I was more than ready to get the baby out, so the possibility of induction didn't scare me. We got Asher for the summer, I finished up my last few weeks of work before maternity leave started, and then... I waited. I did a lot of the things that supposedly start labor when I wasn't at my twice-weekly non-stress tests. At every other NST my OB examined me and was always shocked at how low the baby was, and how thin my cervix was (even though I hadn't started dilating). I felt like it had to be soon.

Wednesday, July 15th was the due date, and even though I was having irregular contractions, some very strong ones, they always went away when I changed positions, and I still hadn't dilated any. At the advice of my mother we went bowling that night to try to start labor. It didn't work, but I swear the baby dropped even lower, if that was at all possible. However, it was nice to spend some time with just the three of us--James, Asher, and me. It would our last outing as a group of three. 

I had another NST the afternoon of July 16th. Even though I had gotten to bed at a decent hour, I still slept in until noon (which I would be very thankful for in the next few days!). I quickly had to get ready, wake up Asher (who had also slept in that late), and get us to the OB's office for yet another NST. I had had one that Monday and the baby hadn't moved around as much as they would have liked, so I had had to have yet another ultrasound. My amniotic fluid had dropped even lower, from a 8.2 to around a 6. Eight was the minimum level I had been told was okay before, but my OB still felt everything was fine and had let me go. Well, at this NST, yet again the baby didn't move as much as they wanted, I had another ultrasound, and the amniotic fluid had dropped even lower, below a five. We were told to wait in a room for my OB--James had taken the afternoon off from work so he could be there this time, so he, Asher, and I were all waiting in the room--but not for too long. My OB came in and immediately said " Your amniotic fluid is getting too low and we'll need to induce you. Do you want to be induced tonight or tomorrow morning?" I could have dropped down to my knees and sang the Hallelujah Chorus at that point--and in my mind, that's exactly what I was doing. I was completely ready to get the process started that night, and I just needed at least an hour and a half for my parents to drive up to be able to watch Asher while James and I were in the hospital. We did some last minute errands, went out for supper with my parents when they arrived, and checked in at 7:00 that evening. 

After being asked if I had a birth plan and answering that my plan was to get the baby out and that an epidural would be nice (I think the nurses were relieved I was such an easy patient), they got me started on the pitocin at 8:00. The baby was at +2 station (the nurses all thought that was a typo until they checked for themselves and realized yes, the baby really was that low) and my cervix was still very thin, but hadn't dilated before getting the pit. After a few hours I was dilating, but not as fast as they would have liked, so they made the decision to break my water and also give me an epidural, since the nurse told me that my contractions would likely get much more intense at that point. I got the epidural at about 1:30 AM. The anesthesiologist looked very tired and out of it, but she was quick and efficient, and it didn't hurt a bit--getting the IV in my hand earlier was much more painful. About half an hour later, my water was broken. Because I had already gotten the epidural, I didn't feel a thing. I tried to sleep but didn't really get a lot--thank goodness I had slept in so late the previous day!

In the morning, when the nurses switched shifts, our day nurse told us how long she was scheduled for that day and said "by the time I leave, you'll have that baby!' I wish I could remember her name; she was awesome. They were raising my pit levels little by little and my labor was progressing with stronger contractions--I only knew they were stronger because I could see the readout on the computer screen, mind you. The epidural was doing its job fantastically and I couldn't feel a thing below my chest. James and I watched a little TV, and my parents and stepson came by later that morning to see how were were doing. The morning was pretty uneventful, other than me suddenly getting very nauseous at one point. They ran anti-nausea medication through the IV and I had almost instant relief. At the rate I was progressing, our nurse guessed I'd be delivering our baby late afternoon or early evening.

Around noon, James went and got lunch and brought it back to the room so he could eat and still be there with me. Almost instantly after he finished I started to feel pain for the first time, both in my vaginal and rectal area. It wasn't unbearable, but it was definitely noticeable and a lot of pressure, so I had James go out and tell our nurse, thinking that my epidural was failing. The nurse came in very excited, telling me that this was good news. She checked me and, lo and behold, I was nine and a half centimeters dilated. I would be pushing sooner than I thought!

Pretty soon the room was crowded with people. I had been asked if I minded a number of different people to observe the birth--such is giving birth in a teaching hospital. I said yes to all of them, figuring they had to learn somehow. Some of them told me that they had witness a number of c-sections, but never a vaginal birth, which I found odd. With all of these people in the room, though, no one could find my OB. My body and baby weren't going to wait--I was soon fully dilated, and was getting the first comments about the baby--"wow, that is a LOT of hair". This was literally everyone's reaction when looking at me as they were getting me into the birthing position. I was offered a mirror to have a look for myself, and while I hadn't planned on using a mirror at all, curiosity finally got the better of me thanks to literally everyone commenting on it, so they positioned the mirror and... yes. The first look I got of my daughter was her very full head of dark, dark hair. My OB still wasn't there, but our main nurse told us that we couldn't wait--it was time to push. As she told us she'd been a labor and delivery nurse for about thirty years I wasn't worried--she definitely knew what she was doing. She got all of the medical students and my husband into position and made note of what time it was when I started to push--1:29 PM.

Pushing was horrible. I still had the epidural so it didn't hurt (at first) but it was completely exhausting, and I quickly began to dread every time I was told to push again. I felt that I wasn't making any progress and had to keep asking James and my OB (who finally arrived after a few minutes of me pushing) if I was progressing at all. They all assured me I was and that I was doing great, but I sure didn't feel like it. Every push was exhausting and took more and more out of me, and I kept having to do it, over and over.

I think it was about an hour into the pushing when I started to feel the contractions and didn't have to be told to push. I'm guessing that they either forgot or didn't bother to top of my epidural at that point. The contractions weren't painful, but I was able to say "do I need to push now?" before anyone had the chance to tell me. By that point I could tell she was so close, but I was just losing stamina and I remember saying at one point "I don't think I can do this anymore." Again everyone told me that I was doing great and it wouldn't be much longer now, and I could tell how close I was, I could feel her head nearly out of me, I felt just one more push should do it... one more push didn't do it... maybe this one... okay, maybe this one...

And then suddenly I'm no longer feeling pressure there and James shouts "She's out!" I don't exactly remember everything that happened at this point. Like I said, I was utterly exhausted and was in a bit of a daze, the whole "did I just give birth?" sort of daze. I remember thinking "why isn't she crying, shouldn't I be hearing a cry right about now?" but then I did, not a very loud one but still hearty-sounding. "Here's your baby!" my OB said, holding up this little wrinkled, bunched-up baby with a full head of hair with skin grayer than I was expecting (I later learned that her skin colorization was pretty normal for being only just out of the womb). It was 2:42 PM on Friday, July 17, 2015.

Not too long after holding her up for me to see, my OB handed my baby to me. "Hi, Lydia," I said to her and put her on my chest. By now she was crying pretty strongly. I put her to my breast in an attempt to nurse her, but my aim was off and she ended up bruising me to the side of the nipple, when she wasn't busy crying. I didn't even notice the bruise at first, though--because I was noticing a lot more pain down where Lydia had just exited me. My OB and a few of the medical students were still down there and I felt like I was getting stabbed with a white-hot knife repeatedly. I realized that I must have been getting stitches, and I asked James, "Did I tear?" He looked at me like I was nuts and said, "uh, no, they cut you." I had had an episiotomy and didn't even realize until after the fact. I worried at first that I had gotten one simply because I had momentarily wimped out and thought I couldn't do it anymore, but James later told me that Lydia hadn't actually been moving the last few pushes before the episiotomy. But apparently, once my OB made that cut, then Lydia just slipped right out. Perhaps I should be upset that it was done without asking me first, but knowing the mental state I was in at the time, my OB could have said "we need to cut off your legs and disembowel you to get this baby out" and I would have said "YES YES DO ANYTHING JUST GET HER OUT", so it's all good.

However, the stitches were not. Now I knew that the epidural had worn off because I felt EVERYTHING. I was wincing and holding a crying newborn and still mentally in a daze that I was actually holding my daughter and... suddenly my chest felt warm and sticky. "Uh, I think she pooped on me!" I announced. Our main nurse took her from me momentarily to clean both her and me up, because yes, she had indeed pooped on me.

Soon enough, Lydia was back on my chest (with a diaper on) and my OB and all of the medical students in the room were congratulating me. The stitches were done and everyone began filing out one by one. Soon it was just me, James, and Lydia, which was nice. I don't regret having all of those students in the room as they were a big help and I was glad to be able to help them in their education, but things were pretty busy and chaotic with so many bodies in the room and it was great to have the opportunity to wind down a bit and get to enjoy our first moments with Lydia, who had calmed down and was gaining the new-baby color I was expecting. After our hour together, we called our parents to tell them the news, Lydia was weighed and measured (and came in at 7 lbs 8 oz and 20 inches long, a completely average sized baby despite my fears to the contrary), and then we were wheeled up to our recovery room!

I could go on and on, as Lydia's birth is only the beginning, one small part of her story. But, then again, her story has only just begun and I will probably never be able to finish it. Lydia Jane has so far been nothing but a joy, and I'm so glad that my husband and I changed each other's minds about having (more) babies.

We're going to the Husker game against Northwestern because I hate myself and want to cry on my birthday. (We're 3-4 this season, and those four losses have all literally been in the last SECONDS of the game. It's heartbreaking to be a Nebraskan this year, lol. But they played a good game last weekend, so hopefully they keep their act together for my birthday too!)

This is a post I can't make on Facebook. I just can't. I have a number of friends--women who are wonderful people, mind you--who post articles and statuses about the very things I'm bitching about right here. And this has been building up for awhile--even when I was pregnant. Hell, even before I got pregnant. The whole "you're a whole different person when you become a mother! Unless if you've squeezed a baby out of your vagina, you DON'T KNOW REAL LOVE." And I thought, hell, maybe I really don't get it. Maybe having a baby will make me get it. Well, I have a baby now. And I still don't get it. (I apologize in advance that this entry will, like most of my journal entries, be long and rambling. And slightly bitchy. But also very depressed on account of these mothers who lose all sense of identity after having a kid. Also, possibly TMI talk about my boobs? lol) What ended up pushing me over the edge and having to write something was a friend of mine posting a couple of articles from this blog: http://thenewlywifedlife.blogspot.com/ You know, inspiring stuff, the whole "I totally needed this today!" post. All fine and dandy. I took a look at the blog, read through some of the posts... and oh my god, this is one of the most depressing blogs I have ever read. I mean, you have to look for them, but there's plenty of entries where the new mother talks about how much she struggled with breastfeeding for the first six months of her daughter's life, so much that her baby was actually failing to gain weight. Even now, her baby who is almost a year old weighs barely more than my own baby who's only two months old. And while my baby is in the 80th percentile, she's not, you know, the 110th percentile or anything. She's not an abnormally large baby or anything. Even though she supposedly has the hang of breastfeeding, her child is still very, very small for her age. And I don't know, maybe it's genetic. Maybe that is a healthy for her child. But that baby just looks so... emaciated. There is a cult of breastfeeding. All of the moms who are so gung-ho about it will tell you that breastfeeding is completely discouraged anymore, that formula is encouraged over it. Now I will admit that there are definitely prudes and jerks out there who for whatever reason get offended when a mother, even discretely, just pops out a boob to feed her baby. And yes, that's ridiculous. Feeding a baby is a boob's function. ...but that's just it. They're functional. They have a job to do, and for the women who are able to utilize them for their intended purpose (more on that in a minute), that's just great. They're a means to an end. They're not some all-mighty magical healing glands of amazingness that all must bow down and worship, they do not have magic and instant bonding powers that will tie you and your baby together with love until the end of time, and they do not cure any and all ills and give your child superpowers. So personal story time. When I was pregnant with Lydia, I was wanting to at least try to breastfeed her, even though I was actually realistic and knew that it might not work. (If genetics are anything to go by, luck was not on my side--my mom's reaction when I told her I was wanting to try was "Well, good luck. I tried with all three of you, too, but could never get it to work.") I read all of the statistics about how breastfed babies are less likely to get sick, more likely to have a higher IQ, how breastfeeding mothers lose the pregnancy weight faster and are less likely to develop breast and ovarian cancer, and those were all nice perks and all, but I have to admit the main reason I wanted to breastfeed was a practical (and lazy) one--I'm cheap as fuck. Formula is super expensive. Why would I spend buttloads of money on food for my kid when my body could produce it for free? Having said all that, I was always prepared for the possibility of breastfeeding not working out for me, and I accepted that. I went to a class with a lactation consultant while I was still pregnant and armed myself with information, but I didn't have my heart completely set on it. Thank God I didn't, too, because I can't imagine how much WORSE I would have felt when it became clear it wasn't going to work out. Yes, worse. I felt bad enough as it was. The first two days after Lydia was born were spent recovering in the hospital. Another lactation consultant visited us both of those days. And for the record, she was great and a total champ and I wouldn't have lasted even the couple of weeks breastfeeding that I ultimately did without her. I have super flat nipples that really only get pointy when I'm cold, so she got me nipple shells and shields that molded them a bit and gave Lydia something to, you know, actually latch on to. And Lydia had a great latch. My failure to breastfeed was not on her. If my breasts had actually, you know, lactated enough to keep up with her, I'd probably still be breastfeeding her. But you see, that's the problem. My milk came in, alright, but it was really only enough to soak through my bras a bit. Any time I tried nursing Lydia, she never seemed to get much out of it. Gix actually dropped $250 on an electric breast pump, and when I tried pumping for a good forty-five minutes, all that came out were a few drops. I was very quickly at the point where I was only nursing her once a day, with formula the rest of the day, and even with that one nursing she was usually hungry enough afterwards that I'd have to give her a bottle anyway. I wanted to give up, but I'd already bought more nipple shields, plus that friggin expensive breast pump (like I said, I'm cheap and I hate wasting money), so I was still determined to get even that once-or-twice-a-day nursing to work. It wouldn't be breastfeeding with supplemental formula, it would be more like formula-feeding with supplemental breastmilk, but hey, at least all of this breastfeeding paraphernalia to assist with the supposedly "free" breastfeeding would still be put to use! So I looked through all of the books and pamphlets about breastfeeding, childbirth, and babies in general for advice on how to jump-start a low supply. They made me sob and hate myself. Page after page extolling all of breatmilk's benefits. Page after page of tips of how to help a baby's poor latch (helpful for those who have that problem, but it was not my problem) and sore/cracked nipples (again, helpful information but not what I was looking for--breastfeeding was never painful for me in any way). Regarding low supply, however, there was very little. The advice amounted to basically pumping to get the supply up (which did nothing) and to just feed your baby more often to get the supply up, because it's a matter of supply and demand! And I thought, "Excuse me? I'm barely producing anything from my boobs and you're telling me to just shove the baby to the boob and force her to suck and suck with hardly any benefit MORE OFTEN?!" And then--in the ones that even mentioned formula feeding at all--you get to the measly one page about it and the very first sentence is "Breastmilk is best for your baby." Congratulations, Mom, for not giving your baby the best. You suck. That's why I cried. I felt like a failure. But I was also pissed. Pissed at the way that the whole breastfeeding movement, which claims to try to empower women, was belittling women who either wouldn't or couldn't do it "the right way". Pissed that it was implying that my brothers and I should have turned out sickly, fat, and stupid because our mother fed us that terrible formula, when in fact all of us are perfectly healthy and very smart. (My younger brother's working on his PhD in chemistry and physics, for Christ's sake. And he's still skinny as a rail and has run a few half-marathons. My older brother also runs 7-8 miles every single friggin' morning. All of us have climbed at least a couple of mountains in our time. None of us have ever had a major illness. We were all formula fed. Tell me again all of the bad things that'll happen if you feed your kid formula, hmmmmmmmmm? Sorry, ranty tangent over.) Basically, I was pissed enough that I threw away all of the nipple shields and cups, threw away that super-expensive breast pump because it was making me angry and depressed just by looking at it, and announced to Gix that I was done trying even the one morning nursing session. We were going to be feeding Lydia formula only. I was relieved. Lydia ate much better without me trying to force the breastfeeding issue and finally started gaining weight. Gix was happier too since we both were happier. I'm glad I decided to give up on breastfeeding, and I know I would have been even more miserable if I had still continued to try after that. Now, back to the blog. This blogger, while not having the same issues with breastfeeding that I did, still obviously struggled with it. But instead of accepting that it wasn't working for her and her child, she still kept trying, even as her child failed to gain weight, and honestly even the most recent pictures of her child... that poor girl looks very frail. And even more damning--there's a particularly depressing post where she admits that all of the strain on her trying to feed her child, the constant nursing and pumping, has all but destroyed her marriage. She wrote that she and her husband react angrily to each other now and that they're in therapy to try to salvage their marriage. I mean, good that they're trying to work it out and all, but that's honestly so sad that that even happened at all--because it didn't have to happen. She could have used formula. She could have gotten sleep--that baby still wakes several times in the night to nurse--which also seems to be common amongst my breastfeeding friends. Lydia is only two months old and usually wakes up only once in the night--early morning, rather. And the one time she does wake up is getting later and later and I bet by next month she actually will be sleeping through the night. And when she does wake up, sometimes Gix feeds her rather than me. Making the choice to feed her strictly formula has made Gix and I completely equal parents in every respect, and it's working out wonderfully for us. There's no resentment whatsoever. The writer of that blog obviously has a lot of resentment for her husband--and it sounds like he has a lot of resentment too because he has to do all of the cooking and cleaning because she's spending all of her time nursing and pumping. It's just sad. And for what? For all of those supposed breastfeeding benefits? Well, reading up on them, I've discovered two things about the, yes, definitely supposed benefits. Number one, any benefits are very slim. As a lot of preschool and kindergarten teachers seem to say about the issue online, it's impossible to look at their classrooms and pick out which ones were breastfed and which ones were formula fed. And number two, what benefits there are seem to be more a case of correlation than causation. Mothers who breastfeed, for example, tend to be better educated and have a higher income level, which of course is a far better explanation for their babies being healthier and doing better in school. And since I have nowhere else to put this, I'll put it here--another benefit of breastfeeding that's always trumpeted is that it's amazing bonding experience. I have yet to be told exactly how having a living being sucking your tit makes the bonding so much better than anything else. I'm actually able to bond with Lydia better now that I'm feeding her formula, because I'm not stressing out about her getting enough, and I can also actually friggin' see her face (seriously, the people who tout being able to bond with their baby must have tiny boobs or something. My boobs are massive enough that I could barely see her when I breastfed her). Plus, Daddy can bond with her through feeding too! And her grandparents, and uncles, and even her eleven-year-old cousins! Mommy doesn't have a monopoly on baby time anymore! And I'm back at work now, and the thought of pumping multiple times during my work day is so unappealing I can't even. What I'm trying to say is that while there's a lot of benefits to breastfeeding (again, can't knock that it's free--Lydia's going to put us in the poorhouse with how much formula she consumes), there's a lot of benefits to formula-feeding as well. And mothers who formula feed, whether through necessity or through choice, should not be made out to feel like they've failed. Mothers who are truly struggling breastfeeding, to the point where their child is actually losing weight, should NOT be told "Just keep at it!" No, they should be told, "There's nothing wrong with formula, FEED YOUR DAMN KID." But breastfeeding is like... a religion to some women, or something. Look at that blogger's photos. The mother and child ones are nice and all, but there's always a couple of the mother breastfeeding her child. Okay, nothing wrong with that per se, don't get me wrong. Again, I'm not a prude who's offended by seeing a mother nurse her baby--like I said, that's what the boobs are there for. But... why would you get a photo--a professional photo, none the less--of you doing it? Do they also want a professional photo of them bathing their child? Or changing their diaper? Or any of the other normal, day-to-day things that parents do to care for their infant? Should I get a professional photograph of me feeding Lydia a bottle of formula? Or, for the true analogy of why I think it's weird, would these mothers get a professional photograph of themselves eating a hamburger or salad or something? Unless if they're a food critic or something... why? We all know you eat. We really don't need a $300 photo shoot memorializing the fact that you get nourishment. Let's be honest here--those shots aren't really about the baby. Again, you can't even really see the baby's face in them--there's a boob in the way. They're about the boob. They're about the mother. I get such an uncomfortable, smug feeling from them, like they're saying "yeah, look at me feeding my baby the right way." Is this judgmental of me? Yes, probably, and I'm probably a bad person for thinking it, but all of my baby materials rubbing the exact same message in my face is still making me think there's probably a kernel of truth in my gut reaction. I cannot imagine being so smug. I cannot imagine being reduced to my boobs. Back to that blog again--she wrote an entry where she admits that her daughter thinks her BOOB'S name is Mama, not her mama herself. I don't know if it was supposed to be cute or what, and she seemed to write it off as something funny, but again, I just felt so bad for her reading that! Your child cares more about your friggin' tit than you as a person? Again, I get it's a baby, but... damn! Maybe she thinks it's cute, but no way in hell am I going to let any baby of mine build a better relationship with my jugs than with me. (I'm running out of different ways to write breasts.) Am I wrong for not understanding that? Am I wrong for still wanting an identity outside of my daughter? Many mom-bloggers would say yes, that I'm a terrible mother for formula-feeding and going back to work full-time when Lydia was six weeks old and actually--gasp--ENJOYING going back to work and not feeling any guilt for leaving my baby at daycare. I felt well-rounded and complete before I had Lydia--before I even got pregnant, to be honest. I knew who I was and the thought of losing all of that terrified me. Thankfully, it hasn't happened. Sure, my life's a lot different now--I have a baby, after all. Even though she's a very easy-going baby, she still requires a lot of care. I also love the bejesezus out of her. She's also super adorable, but I admit that I'm completely biased. ;) But I'm still me. I'm still that dork who loves cartoons and American history and blasts the classic rock radio station in the car when Lydia's not in it (I turn the volume down a bit when she is--gotta expose her to awesome music early!), who likes alone time and still makes time to cuddle with her husband every now and then. Lydia added to my life. She didn't take over my life. And yes, I actually DID know what real love is before I had her. I love my husband. I love my parents. So the month of May has really sucked and I'm glad to see it go in a few days. For about a week after that, we had only one car (mine), which meant that I was driving him to work, then going to work myself, then going to pick him up after I got off work, then driving him all the way to his musical rehearsal, then dicking around for the two hours or so he was in rehearsal, then driving us home. This whole process went from about 7 AM to roughly 8:30 or 9 PM. Anyway... we finally got Gix's car back tonight, but pretty much two minutes after driving it out of the insurance service center, the check engine light came on saying to check the emissions. (facepalm) Gix called the dealer and it's probably nothing, but he'll still probably have to bring it in on Monday just in case. Which means I get to drive him around again, since we're bringing my brother's car back to him on Sunday. With Gix's musical rehearsal schedule, it's pretty much the best time to do it. As for me. I took a standard glucose tolerance test at my OB appointment a few weeks ago to check for the likelihood of gestational diabetes. My first test showed high glucose levels, so I had to take a longer one on Wednesday. Got the results yesterday... and they were also high. Which means I have gestational diabetes. FML. I went to the store tonight to buy foods that I can, you know, actually eat, and it's hardly ANYTHING. I mean, knowing what I previously knew about diabetes, I just thought "oh, well okay then, I'll have to cut out sugar, but that's okay since I don't really eat or drink a lot of sweet stuff." Oh no. I have to cut carbs as well. CARBS. That's pretty much all I eat. Sandwiches, pasta, potatoes... From what I read online, I'm allowed 45-60 grams of carbs a day, which seems like a lot, but it's really not. Like, at all. I'm already at 56 and I'm still hungry and let me tell you, pretty much every food on EARTH has at least some carbs in it. I'm not just hungry. I'm HANGRY. Like all I want is a slice of pizza or a big bacon cheeseburger or even some spaghetti but NO, no can do! I was excited to see that I can drink milk, but then I saw a serving of milk has eleven grams of carbs. ELEVEN! I have one glass of milk right now and I've already pushed myself over the limit. SHIT GODDAMN FUCK ALL I WANT IS SOME GODDAMN MILK IS THAT TOO MUCH TO FUCKING ASK?! (And yes, it's skim milk.) Sorry about the swearing. ^^; I'm just super pissed that this happened. I had absolutely none of the risk factors for developing gestational diabetes, and like I said I don't even eat a ton of sweets anyway, so I have no clue how this happened rather than just rotten luck. And all the carbs, I suppose. The good news is that the diabetes should hopefully go away after I've given birth. Also, another weird thing of good news... and good news that I probably shouldn't consider good news... but I've read that when a mother has gestational diabetes, they often like to do an induction or C-section between 37-39 weeks, because of the risk of having a bigger baby. I'm at 33 weeks right now, and let me tell you, I am SO OVER being pregnant. I'm not even really having a difficult pregnancy (besides, you know, the diabetes and all) and I'm still miserable. I hate not being able to easily get up out of bed and stand up from chairs, I hate moving so slowly and still getting winded from walking any sort of distance, I hate not being able to get comfortable when I'm trying to sleep, I hate not being able to drink, and now I hate not being able to actually eat stuff that's more than just fruits or a salad or grilled chicken. And if anyone says "stop complaining about being pregnant, thousands of women would give anything to get pregnant", then you can shove it. I understand to an extent. I miscarried last year. I can be happy to be having a baby while still hating the process it takes to actually get it into the world. I'll be meeting with a nutritionist in about a week and a half. Hopefully he or she will tell me I can eat a little more than a "normal" diabetic can because of being pregnant and all. Then I have another OB appointment, with an untrasound (another perk of having GD, I suppose) so we can see how baby's doing and how big she is. Oh, and speaking of that and bringing me back to the possible early induction/C-section... this diagnosis has just made me feel like it's even more likely that I'll have a C-section. Ever since I've started feeling this baby move inside of me, every movement has been very, very low. I would say that I haven't felt anything past my bellybutton level, but even that's a lie, because I don't think I've felt anything even that high. At my appointment a few weeks ago I mentioned this to my OB, who felt my (big, protruding) bump and told me "yep, she's lying in there horizontally". She told me that the baby still had a few weeks to move, but having felt no change so far and the fact that she seems to like that position, I highly doubt she will by this point. And if she's in that position, then a C-section is pretty much necessary. And while I know that's a major surgery and all... I was/am so dreading labor and all of the variables that go into it that I'm almost relieved to know that this baby will most likely be sliced out of me in a process that only takes around 45 minutes (and one I'll have at least a little bit of advanced notice of, so I'll have a few days to prepare). Granted, I'm getting ahead of myself, since I don't know whether or not I'll be giving birth vaginally yet at this point, but with the horizontal position plus the diabetes, I'm thinking right now it's pretty unlikely. But we'll probably have a better idea at my upcoming ultrasound. Sorry for the rant. I needed to get this off of my chest. I've been stressed out and feeling like I'm near my breaking point for awhile now. Let's just hope June will be better. And who knows... maybe the last week of June I'll already be holding my daughter?
